Geraldine has enlisted Romero to help her recoup her debts, and Romero works to con unsuspecting Freedmen  Black individuals who were formerly enslaved by Native American tribes  out of valuable land in Oklahoma. Romero receives a letter from an offie in Oklahoma about a lease of land. "Manuel Romero, Dear Sir, I was informed at register's office that you would have to properly identify Helen Childers signature. Would advise that you procure six affidavits. And send for at once. Yours truly, James Davis".

As a result of treaties between the U.S. federal government and Native American tribes in now-Oklahoma, the once-communal land had been divided into individual allotments. When oil and gas was discovered, making those land allotments extremely valuable,

white settlers used legal guardianship and other means of abuse to manipulate the land, money, and legal power from their rightful Native American owners, which was enabled by various federal policies
. For Freedmen, former enslaved people of the Native American tribes, this was made even more complex by many tribes' refusal to acknowledge federal treaties regarding their citizenship rights.

Beatrice George as Mother Agnes. Mother Agnes is a matronly woman who helps young colored girls in need of a home. She is actually Agnes Childers, who came to California from Oklahoma seeking her long-lost daughter, Helen. By the end of the film, Juanita discovers that she is Helen Childers and that Mother Agnes is actually her birth mother.

Screenplay by George P. Johnson (b. 1885). George is the brother of the Noble M. Johnson, a prolific Hollywood actor and co-founder of the Lincoln Motion Picture Company. George was brought on to be the general booking manager in 1916. After his brothers resignation from the company, George pitched the idea for this fifth and final Lincoln film. Hear him talk about the idea here:

children.text: Pinky, a chauffeur and bumbling detective, played by Webb King. Pinky has been hired by the Mexican American attorney Manuel Romero to track down a missing Creek Freedmen  Black individuals who were formerly enslaved by Native American tribes  named Helen Childers, so that Romero can trick her into signing away her land. Pinky's role provides some comic relief to the story, as seen here in his "disguise."

The majority of the film takes place in southern California in the 1920s, but there are missing scenes that take place in Oklahoma, and fashbacks to around 1906, a year before Oklahoma statehood. Romero makes a trip to Oklahoma in the scenario, and the Oklahoma sequence included an appearance by Minnie Prevost (Cheyenne and Arapaho), also known as "Indian Minnie," or "Minnie Ha-Ha." Minnie performed in numerous Hollywood and independent films during her lifetime. In this film, she plays Minnie, an aged Indian woman, herself recently enriched through oil developments (and who retains all her unpolished habits and primitive customs, which contrast comically with the luxury and splendor with which she now surrounds herself. Minnie tells Romero the property belonged to the daughter of her nephew John Childers, whose wife had been a Colored Freedman. The family migrated to California years ago, and she had not heard from them since.

Juanita Cooper, played by Anita Thompson (also known as Anita Thompson Dickinson Reynolds). A cousin of Langston Hughes, she had studied dance with Ruth St. Denis, and belonged to a well-known family of Black activists and socialites. She claimed her grandmother was Native American. W.E.B. DuBois featured her on the cover of the May 1917 issue of The Crisis. Thompson was still a high school student when she assumed her role in By Right of Birth. children.text: Philip Jones, played by Clarence Brooks. Philip is a track star and brilliant young Colored Law student, who admires Juanita Cooper, the adopted daughter of Frank and Geraldine Cooper. Clarence Brooks, along with his older brother Dudley Brooks, Noble Johnson, and a pharmacist named James T. Smith, was one of the co-founders of the Lincoln Motion Picture Company. He became the companys male lead after Noble Johnsons resignation from the company.

children.text: Romero, at the bequest of Juanita's adoptive mother Geraldine, has been tracking down the owner of a lucrative lease in Oklahoma, and realizes Helen Childers is Juanita. Assured of her real identity, he tries to manipulate her into signing away her allotment for an insignificant sum. His efforts are thwarted by Philip, who comes to protect Juanita. A fight ensues as Philip tries to retrieve the lease, leading to a car chase in which Romero is accidentally killed.
